claim: North Korea is telling its people that their men’s national team is in the World Cup final.
summarized_text: The article discusses a YouTube video that appears to be a North Korean news broadcast previewing the final match of the 2014 World Cup. The video suggests that North Korea's team made it to the final and will face Portugal. However, the video is actually a fake and was created by an anonymous producer of the YouTube channel Korea News Backup. The article mentions that some bloggers and journalists believed that North Korea was trying to deceive its citizens with this video. However, the video is clearly a spoof and not an actual news broadcast. The article also addresses the reasons why the North Korean government would be unlikely to attempt such a stunt. Firstly, state-controlled media had been broadcasting the World Cup games, although not live. Additionally, most North Koreans would be aware that their team failed to qualify for the World Cup two years prior. The article quotes experts who explain that making it to the final would be impossible for North Korea on sporting grounds. The article also highlights some examples of creative license exercised by the North Korean government. For instance, the official biography of the previous leader, Kim Jong Il, claimed that he was born on Mount Baekdu, a sacred place in Korean culture. However, historians believe he was actually born on Russian soil near Vladivostok. Another example is a sports myth that Kim Jong Il scored multiple holes-in-one during his first time playing golf. The details of this myth have changed over time, with different sources reporting different numbers of holes-in-one. In conclusion, the article debunks the claim that North Korea was telling its people that their national team was in the World Cup final. The video in question is a satire and not an actual news broadcast. The article also provides reasons why the North Korean government would not attempt such a stunt and highlights other instances of creative license exercised by the government.

The video was satire and bore unmistakable markings, for any Korean speaker, of having not come from the communist country. Plus, North Korea had been broadcasting the World Cup and any soccer fan there would know that their team failed to qualify.

claim: Clamor for GSK shingles shot points to bigger profits.
summarized_text: GlaxoSmithKline (GSK) is facing a problem as demand for its shingles vaccine, Shingrix, is outstripping supply. The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has warned of shortages as more than 1.5 million Americans have received the vaccine since the end of last year. GSK has increased deliveries significantly and is vaccinating people against shingles at a faster rate than before, but it is struggling to keep up with the high demand. The CDC has recommended Shingrix over Merck's older and less effective vaccine, leading to strong demand. Consensus forecasts predict peak annual sales for Shingrix of around £1.5 billion ($2 billion), but Exane BNP analysts believe this estimate may be too low. They suggest sales could rise to £3 billion if Shingrix achieves market penetration rates of around 60%, similar to Pfizer's pneumonia vaccine Prevnar. In its first full quarter on the market, Shingrix achieved sales of £110 million, and GSK expects 2018 sales to exceed £400 million. Shingrix is a key product for GSK CEO Emma Walmsley as she aims to improve the company's commercial performance and demonstrate the profit potential of GSK's vaccines business. GSK has already achieved its mid-term goal of reaching vaccine margins of 30%, and Exane BNP believes it could reach 35% by 2020 with the introduction of Shingrix and other premium vaccines. Shingrix is administered in two doses, while Merck's Zostavax is a single shot. Ensuring patients adhere to the two-shot regimen will be crucial in maximizing the vaccine's sales potential. Shingles is caused by the reactivation of the varicella zoster virus, which is also responsible for chickenpox. The virus lies dormant in the nervous system of nearly all adults over 50, putting them at risk of shingles as they age.
label: true
explanation: GlaxoSmithKline is facing “unprecedented” demand for its new shingles vaccine Shingrix, suggesting the product could be a bigger money-spinner than the company and analysts initially thought.

claim: Senate OKs Coast Guard bill with ballast water compromise.
summarized_text: The Senate has approved a Coast Guard budget authorization bill that includes provisions for regulating the disposal of ballast water, which is used to stabilize vessels in rough seas but can introduce unwanted organisms to US waters. The bill, which has been sent to the House for consideration, would see the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) set national rules for ballast and other water discharges, with the Coast Guard responsible for enforcement. The bill also prohibits states from imposing stricter treatment rules than those set by the EPA, except in the Great Lakes region, where regional requirements could be imposed if enough of the eight states that border the lakes want them. The bill authorizes $10.6bn for the Coast Guard in fiscal year 2019, a 16% increase from 2017, which will be used to modernize the fleet of cutters and aircraft. The bill also contains provisions to help the agency crack down on drug smuggling and enforce borders, as well as boost efforts to respond to oil spills and build a National Coast Guard Museum. The bill has been praised by both the shipping industry and environmentalists, although debate is expected to continue over the strength of the regulations. The current federal policy limits the number of live organisms in ballast water before it is discharged, but environmentalists argue that the international standards are too weak. The EPA has been ordered by a federal court to strengthen the standards, but shippers claim that the technology available cannot meet the cleanliness targets demanded by environmentalists.
label: true
explanation: The U.S. Senate approved a compromise policy Wednesday on dumping ship ballast water in coastal ports and the Great Lakes, a practice blamed for spreading invasive species that damage the environment and the economy.

The bill authorizes $10.6bn for the Coast Guard in fiscal year 2019, a 16% increase from 2017, which will be used to modernize the fleet of cutters and aircraft. claim: Reverend urges Lee to act during Nashville MLK Day event.

Lee is against expanding Medicaid in Tennessee and raising the minimum wage. A Lee spokesman says, “Freedom allows for different opinions, and that is what makes this country the special place it is.”
label: true

claim: A ham and cheese sandwich on one slice of bread is the responsibility of the USDA ... But a ham and cheese sandwich on two slices of bread is the responsibility of the Food and Drug Administration.
summarized_text: The article discusses a claim made by Hillary Clinton during a campaign speech in Shenandoah, Iowa. Clinton argued that the federal government is not adequately protecting the public due to insufficient inspections of toys and food. She used the example of a ham and cheese sandwich to illustrate her point, stating that a sandwich on one slice of bread falls under the jurisdiction of the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA), which conducts daily inspections of manufacturers. However, a sandwich on two slices of bread is the responsibility of the Food and Drug Administration (FDA), which only inspects manufacturers about once every five years. To verify Clinton's claim, the article refers to government reports on food safety, interviews with the head of the USDA's food inspection service, and the government's Food Standards and Labeling Policy Book. It confirms that Clinton's example is correct, highlighting the significant disparity in inspections conducted by the two agencies. Richard Raymond, the USDA's undersecretary for food safety, acknowledged the absurdity of the sandwich rule and admitted that it defies logic. However, he stated that the rule does not impact the safety of the nation's food supply. The article explains that the distinction between USDA and FDA jurisdiction over sandwiches can be traced back to Upton Sinclair's novel, The Jungle, published in 1906. The book exposed horrific conditions in meat plants and led to the enactment of a law requiring meat inspections. Since then, the USDA has focused on meat and poultry inspections, while other foods fall under the FDA's purview. The FDA, however, does not have a mandate for regular inspections, and a report by the Government Accountability Office confirms that the agency inspects the 57,000 food plants under its jurisdiction about once every five years on average. Caroline Smith DeWaal, food safety director for the Center for Science in the Public Interest, criticizes the current food safety system, stating that it is based on antiquated laws and divided agencies. She argues that the lack of regular inspections and insufficient funding for the FDA puts the public at risk. These concerns are echoed in a report from an FDA advisory panel, which states that the agency is overburdened and underfunded, making it unable to effectively conduct routine surveillance of the nation's food supply. In conclusion, the article confirms that Hillary Clinton's claim about the regulation of sandwiches and the disparity in inspections by the USDA and FDA is accurate. It highlights the historical background of the distinction between the two agencies and raises concerns about the current food safety system's ability to protect the public.
label: true
explanation: A legitimate beef with ham sandwich regulations

Finland's liquor retail agency, Alko, recalled Fireball and offered refunds, stating that propylene glycol is not necessarily detrimental to health but is used in a wide range of products. The Swedish state alcohol retailer, Systembolaget, also withdrew Fireball from distribution after concerns over excessive levels of propylene glycol. The regulatory policies regarding propylene glycol in Finland and Sweden are stricter than in the US. The European Union permits smaller amounts of propylene glycol in products. The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) in the US considers propylene glycol to be safe when used in foods and beverages at levels not exceeding current good manufacturing practice. The rumors that Fireball was recalled in Europe because it contains antifreeze are inaccurate. Propylene glycol, which is found in Fireball, is less toxic and more environmentally safe than the antifreeze that contains ethylene glycol. The amount of propylene glycol used in foods and liquors is limited, and it would be difficult to ingest a dangerous amount through food or drink. The European recalls were not prompted by a change in Fireball's composition but rather due to differing regulatory protocols in different countries. Fireball issued a statement explaining that a logistical mix-up caused bottles intended for the North American market to be shipped to Finland. The brand assured consumers that all formulations are safe to drink and that there is no recall in North America. Fireball fans can continue to enjoy the product as they always have.
Claim: Fireball whisky is being recalled due to concerns over a dangerous ingredient.

claim: The state GOP ticket "says their top priority is a career-long mission to outlaw abortion in all cases and ban some common forms of birth control.
summarized_text: Members of the Democratic state ticket in Virginia have labeled their Republican opponents as extremists, claiming that their top priority is to outlaw abortion in all cases and ban some common forms of birth control. The claim was made by Terry McAuliffe, the Democratic gubernatorial nominee, during a campaign rally in Richmond. McAuliffe's campaign pointed to a comment made by Republican candidate Ken Cuccinelli at a rally in 2012, where he advocated for personhood legislation. However, the Truth-O-Meter fact-checking website argues that this comment is not relevant to the claim at hand. While it is clear that the GOP ticket opposes abortion, there is no evidence that they have proclaimed ending abortion and restricting birth control as their top priority. Cuccinelli has stated that his top priority is the economy and job creation. McAuliffe's campaign also provided snippets of other comments made by Cuccinelli, where he expressed his opposition to abortion, but again, these fall short of a declaration of their top priority. The article concludes that while it is likely that the GOP ticket will do everything possible to restrict abortions and potentially ban certain types of birth control, McAuliffe's claim goes beyond what has been stated by his opponents.
label: false
explanation: McAuliffe claimed the GOP ticket "says their top priority is a career-long mission to outlaw abortion in all cases and ban some common forms of birth control." A compelling argument can be made that members of the GOP ticket will do everything possible to restrict abortions and those actions could ban certain types of birth control. But McAuliffe went an extra step and put words in the mouths of his opponents.

claim: A man was arrested after sugar from his Krispy Kreme donuts tested positive for methamphetamine during a traffic stop.
summarized_text: In December 2015, Daniel Frederick Rushing was arrested in Orlando, Florida after a traffic stop. The police found a "rock-like substance" on the floorboard of his car, which they suspected to be methamphetamine. Rushing claimed that the substance was actually glaze from a Krispy Kreme donut that he had been eating. Despite his explanation, Rushing was arrested and charged with possession of amphetamine with a weapon. He was jailed for ten hours before lab reports came back showing no trace of illegal substances. This incident is not an isolated case. Investigative journalists found that up to half of the positive results from the $2 drug kits used by Florida police for field testing are later invalidated. In one instance, Hillsborough County sheriff's deputies produced 15 false positives for methamphetamine in just seven months. The tests have been known to mistake harmless substances like sage, motor oil, jolly ranchers, and breath mints for illegal drugs. In another case, a Minnesota man spent months in jail after his vitamin powder tested positive for amphetamines. The article also mentions that there is no central agency regulating the use of drug tests in police departments, and there are no comprehensive records about their use. In Austin, Texas, law enforcement stopped relying on field tests for drug-related indictments in 2013 due to the high number of false positives. Instead, they returned to slower lab test results for suspected drug offenses. This incident highlights the issue of false positives in drug field tests. Rushing plans to sue the city for his wrongful arrest, although the Orlando police claim that the arrest was lawful. The article emphasizes the need for more reliable drug testing methods and better regulation of the use of drug tests in law enforcement.
label: true

claim: Study finds Americans are eating more - and more often.
summarized_text: A study conducted by researchers at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill found that the number of daily meals and snacks consumed by U.S. adults has increased over the past 30 years. In 1977, adults consumed an average of 3.8 meals and snacks per day, but by 2006, this number had risen to 4.8. In the top 10 percent of those surveyed, the number of daily meals and snacks increased from five to seven. Although the size of meal portions has stabilized in recent years, the study found that the number of total calories consumed is rising. Americans were consuming 570 more calories per day in 2006 compared to the late 1970s. One of the main contributors to this calorie gain is the increased consumption of sugar-sweetened soft drinks, which has risen by 220 calories daily since the 1960s. The study is the first to examine the combined contribution of changes in portion sizes, the caloric level of foods, and eating frequency on people's total calorie consumption. It was funded by the National Institutes of Health and published in the journal PLoS Medicine. According to Kiyah Duffey, one of the study's authors, large portion sizes drove the rise in calories during the early part of the study period. However, as people became more aware of portion sizes, there was a decline in the portion sizes they consumed. Duffey suggests that in recent decades, the increase in the number of eating occasions is driving the change in calorie consumption. The availability of food and a decline in regular mealtimes may be contributing to this pattern. Duffey explains that people are no longer sitting down to three meals a day but are eating throughout the day. Some sources of dieting and health advice claim that frequent eating in small doses can boost metabolism and control hunger, suggesting it is a healthier way of eating than having three big meals. However, Duffey emphasizes that what and how much you eat over the course of the day is more important than how often you eat. She advises choosing healthier options like apples instead of salty snacks or pizza.
label: true
explanation: Americans may be cutting back on super-sized meals, but waistlines continue to expand from more frequent eating, according to a study released on Wednesday.

However, as people became more aware of portion sizes, there was a decline in the portion sizes they consumed. The availability of food and a decline in regular mealtimes may be contributing to this pattern. Duffey explains that people are no longer sitting down to three meals a day but are eating throughout the day. Some sources of dieting and health advice claim that frequent eating in small doses can boost metabolism and control hunger, suggesting it is a healthier way of eating than having three big meals. However, Duffey emphasizes that what and how much you eat over the course of the day is more important than how often you eat. She advises choosing healthier options like apples instead of salty snacks or pizza.
Claim: Study finds Americans are eating more - and more often.

claim: Legal pot sales begin in Uruguay under landmark 2013 law.
summarized_text: Customers in Uruguay are now able to legally purchase marijuana from authorized pharmacies, thanks to a 2013 law that made Uruguay the first country to legalize a pot market covering the entire chain from plants to purchase. The law was implemented in an effort to combat rising homicide and crime rates associated with drug trafficking. Nearly 5,000 people have registered as consumers, allowing them to buy up to 40 grams of marijuana per month using fingerprint recognition. The price is set at $1.30 per gram, with the majority of the revenue going to the two businesses chosen to cultivate marijuana. The rest is split between the pharmacies and the government, which will use its share to fund prevention programs. The marijuana comes in packages with a seal of authenticity and warnings about the drug's effects. The law also allows licensed individuals to grow marijuana plants and form clubs. However, polls showed that most Uruguayans opposed the law, and the majority of the country's estimated 1,200 pharmacies decided not to register to sell marijuana. The implementation of the law was delayed due to the ambitious nature of the project, as no other country had attempted such a comprehensive marijuana marketplace. Despite the opposition and challenges, the legalization of marijuana in Uruguay has been widely applauded globally and seen as going beyond marijuana legislation in the US states of Colorado and Washington.

Context: The claim that Fireball whisky is being recalled due to concerns over a dangerous ingredient is partially true. In October 2014, there were rumors on social media that Fireball whisky was being recalled, causing upset among consumers. However, no news reports confirmed this recall. It was later revealed that while Fireball whisky was not being broadly recalled, it was the subject of scrutiny and a partial recall in Finland and Sweden due to the inclusion of propylene glycol. Finland's liquor retail agency, Alko, recalled Fireball and offered refunds, stating that propylene glycol is not necessarily detrimental to health but is used in a wide range of products. The Swedish state alcohol retailer, Systembolaget, also withdrew Fireball from distribution after concerns over excessive levels of propylene glycol. The regulatory policies regarding propylene glycol in Finland and Sweden are stricter than in the US. The European Union permits smaller amounts of propylene glycol in products. The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) in the US considers propylene glycol to be safe when used in foods and beverages at levels not exceeding current good manufacturing practice. The rumors that Fireball was recalled in Europe because it contains antifreeze are inaccurate. Propylene glycol, which is found in Fireball, is less toxic and more environmentally safe than the antifreeze that contains ethylene glycol. The amount of propylene glycol used in foods and liquors is limited, and it would be difficult to ingest a dangerous amount through food or drink. The European recalls were not prompted by a change in Fireball's composition but rather due to differing regulatory protocols in different countries. Fireball issued a statement explaining that a logistical mix-up caused bottles intended for the North American market to be shipped to Finland. The brand assured consumers that all formulations are safe to drink and that there is no recall in North America. Fireball fans can continue to enjoy the product as they always have.
Claim: Fireball whisky is being recalled due to concerns over a dangerous ingredient.

claim: Judge tosses $417M award against Johnson & Johnson.
summarized_text: A Los Angeles County Superior Court Judge, Maren Nelson, has granted Johnson & Johnson's request for a new trial, overturning a $417 million award that was given to a woman who claimed that the company's talcum powder caused her ovarian cancer. The judge stated that there were errors and jury misconduct in the previous trial, and also ruled that there was not enough evidence to prove that Johnson & Johnson acted with malice. The judge further deemed the awarded damages to be excessive. Although the woman, Eva Echeverria, has since passed away, her attorney, Mark Robinson Jr., plans to appeal the decision. He stated that they will continue to fight on behalf of all women who have been impacted by the product. Echeverria had alleged that Johnson & Johnson failed to adequately warn consumers about the potential cancer risks associated with their talcum powder. She had used the company's baby powder daily from the 1950s until 2016 and was diagnosed with ovarian cancer in 2007. Her attorney argued that documents showed that the company had known about the risks for decades. Johnson & Johnson expressed satisfaction with the ruling, stating that ovarian cancer is not caused by the cosmetic-grade talc used in their baby powder. They emphasized that they will continue to defend the safety of their product as they prepare for additional trials in the United States. The company has faced numerous similar allegations, resulting in hundreds of lawsuits and jury awards totaling hundreds of millions of dollars. However, a Missouri appellate court recently overturned a $72 million award to the family of a woman who had died, ruling that the state was not the proper jurisdiction for the case. The court cited a U.S. Supreme Court ruling in June that limited where injury lawsuits could be filed, stating that state courts cannot hear claims against companies not based in the state where the alleged injuries occurred.
label: true
explanation: A judge on Friday tossed out a $417 million jury award to a woman who claimed she developed ovarian cancer by using Johnson & Johnson talc-based baby powder for feminine hygiene.

claim: Quake amputees embody resilience in broken Haiti.
summarized_text: The article discusses the resilience of amputee soccer players in Haiti, who have lost limbs as a result of the devastating earthquake that struck the country in 2010. The players, who train on a dusty pitch near Cite Soleil, Haiti's largest slum, faced off in a match on the anniversary of the earthquake as a commemoration of the disaster. Many people in Haiti lost limbs in the earthquake, and the players have received treatment, athletic training, and prosthetic limbs through a program funded by Miami's Project Medishare and the Knights of Columbus. Over 100 young quake victims have been fitted with limbs so far, with hundreds more set to begin treatment in the coming weeks and months. Despite the uplifting example of the amputee players, there is a sense of pessimism and despair in Haiti. The country was already impoverished before the earthquake, with 70% of the population living on less than $2 a day. The rebuilding efforts have been slow, and major streets in the capital city of Port-au-Prince are still covered in debris. Former U.S. President Bill Clinton, who heads a reconstruction commission, has faced criticism for the lack of tangible results. The anniversary of the earthquake promises little in the way of celebration, with many people expressing disappointment in the lack of progress. The article also mentions the reopening of Port-au-Prince's restored Iron Market as part of the commemoration events. Finland's liquor retail agency, Alko, recalled Fireball and offered refunds, stating that propylene glycol is not necessarily detrimental to health but is used in a wide range of products. The Swedish state alcohol retailer, Systembolaget, also withdrew Fireball from distribution after concerns over excessive levels of propylene glycol. The regulatory policies regarding propylene glycol in Finland and Sweden are stricter than in the US. The European Union permits smaller amounts of propylene glycol in products. The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) in the US considers propylene glycol to be safe when used in foods and beverages at levels not exceeding current good manufacturing practice. The rumors that Fireball was recalled in Europe because it contains antifreeze are inaccurate. Propylene glycol, which is found in Fireball, is less toxic and more environmentally safe than the antifreeze that contains ethylene glycol. The amount of propylene glycol used in foods and liquors is limited, and it would be difficult to ingest a dangerous amount through food or drink. The European recalls were not prompted by a change in Fireball's composition but rather due to differing regulatory protocols in different countries. Fireball issued a statement explaining that a logistical mix-up caused bottles intended for the North American market to be shipped to Finland. The brand assured consumers that all formulations are safe to drink and that there is no recall in North America. Fireball fans can continue to enjoy the product as they always have.
Claim: Fireball whisky is being recalled due to concerns over a dangerous ingredient.

Overall, the article provides information on the benefits of higher calcium intake in reducing cancer risk in older people, but fails to provide context on the absolute risk and risks of excessive calcium intake. claim: Players’ mental health becoming major issue in cricket.
summarized_text: The article discusses the growing issue of mental health among cricket players. It highlights recent cases where players have made themselves unavailable for selection due to mental health concerns. Veteran allrounder Glenn Maxwell and ex-test batsman Nic Maddinson both withdrew from the series against Pakistan, while 21-year-old Will Pucovski informed selectors that he didn't want to be considered for national duties. Pucovski had been playing in an Australia A tour game against Pakistan when he made the decision. The article mentions that mental health issues are not isolated to cricket, with senior England batsmen and India captain Virat Kohli also speaking openly about their struggles. Cricket Australia's national teams manager, Ben Oliver, commended Pucovski for his courage in discussing his situation and emphasized the importance of supporting players facing similar challenges. The article also mentions that player welfare is paramount, and silence is not the answer when it comes to mental health. Cricket Australia's sports medicine manager, Alex Kountouris, stated that there is still much society needs to learn about mental health, but it is clear that openness and support are crucial. The article also highlights the cases of other cricketers who have struggled with mental health issues, such as ex-England captain Marcus Trescothick and England opener Jonathan Trott. It notes that cricket has traditionally placed a strong emphasis on mental toughness, but the sport is now recognizing the importance of addressing mental health concerns. Overall, the article emphasizes the need for greater awareness and support for mental health in cricket. It commends players like Maxwell and Pucovski for speaking out and setting an example for others. The article concludes by stating that cricket is facing a mental health crisis and that the causes of mental anguish in the sport are many and varied.
label: true
explanation: A serious health concern is emerging in Australian cricket. The first test of the home summer starts in Brisbane next week and Australia has three players out of the selection frame because of mental health reasons.

It notes that cricket has traditionally placed a strong emphasis on mental toughness, but the sport is now recognizing the importance of addressing mental health concerns.

Overall, the article emphasizes the need for greater awareness and support for mental health in cricket. It commends players like Maxwell and Pucovski for speaking out and setting an example for others. claim: U.S. travel warning adds to pressure on Tanzania over suspected Ebola cases.
summarized_text: The U.S. State Department has issued an updated travel advisory for U.S. travelers, urging them to "exercise increased caution" due to reports of a probable Ebola-related death in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania. However, Tanzania denies these reports and claims that no cases of Ebola have been confirmed. The government is facing mounting pressure to provide clarification on the situation. The foreign affairs ministry has not yet commented on the U.S. advisory. Authorities in east and central Africa have been on high alert for possible spillovers of Ebola from the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), where an outbreak has already claimed over 2,100 lives. Tanzania shares a border with the DRC, separated by a lake. The World Health Organization (WHO) recently criticized Tanzania for refusing to provide details of suspected Ebola cases, which goes against international health regulations. The WHO expressed concern over the lack of transparency but stated that it has no evidence of Ebola presence in Tanzania. The organization ruled out punitive action and reiterated its advice against travel or trade restrictions. In response to Tanzania's lack of transparency, the head of the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) traveled to Tanzania at the direction of U.S. Health Secretary Alex Azar. Azar had previously criticized Tanzania for not sharing information. Tanzania summoned the WHO's local representative over their assertion of suspected Ebola cases in the country. The government had previously investigated two cases of unknown illnesses, but they tested negative for Ebola. The situation in Tanzania highlights the importance of transparency in combating the deadly and fast-spreading hemorrhagic fever. With the ongoing Ebola outbreak in the neighboring DRC, authorities are on high alert and urging countries to share information to prevent the spread of the disease.
label: true

Fireball issued a statement explaining that a logistical mix-up caused bottles intended for the North American market to be shipped to Finland. The brand assured consumers that all formulations are safe to drink and that there is no recall in North America. Fireball fans can continue to enjoy the product as they always have.
Claim: Fireball whisky is being recalled due to concerns over a dangerous ingredient.

Overall, the article provides information on the benefits of higher calcium intake in reducing cancer risk in older people, but fails to provide context on the absolute risk and risks of excessive calcium intake. Nygard continued to press ahead with the installation, pouring a concrete pad for the turbine after his building permit application was rejected. The city threatened him with criminal prosecution if he did not remove the turbine.

The dispute between Nygard and the city of Orono resulted in multiple lawsuits and a moratorium on small wind conversion systems in the city. Nygard was found to be in contempt of court in October 2015 for failing to comply with an order to remove the turbine's concrete footing. He was sentenced to six months in jail, but the concrete was removed shortly after his sentencing, and he was released after a few days.

The article highlights that stories like Nygard's are often misconstrued or misrepresented as examples of an overreaching government restricting autonomous lifestyles. Similar stories, such as a man being jailed for collecting rainwater or a judge ruling homegrown vegetables unlawful, have been distorted to fit this narrative. In reality, these disputes often involve specific cases and do not represent a widespread crackdown on self-sustainability.

In conclusion, while Jay Nygard did face legal consequences for his wind turbine installation, the claim that he was jailed simply for possessing a windmill on his property oversimplifies the complex legal dispute between Nygard and the city of Orono.
Claim: A Minnesota man was jailed simply for possessing a windmill on his property.

claim: Texas ranks: 1 in worker deaths, 1 carbon emissions, 50 in high school graduates, 50 in funding for mental health patients.
summarized_text: The claim states that Texas ranks 1 in worker deaths, 1 in carbon emissions, 50 in high school graduates, and 50 in funding for mental health patients. The article examines each of these claims individually. Regarding worker deaths, the article cites various sources that indicate Texas had the highest number of worker fatalities in 2010. However, when adjusting for population, Texas ranked 18th in worker deaths per 100,000 workers. Among states with more than 1 million employed, Texas ranked 10th. In terms of carbon emissions, Texas did have the highest amount of CO2 emissions in 2010. However, when adjusting for population, Texas would have tied for 13th place. The article also notes that Texas has a large number of industrial facilities, such as oil refineries and chemical plants, which contribute to its high emissions. Regarding high school graduates, the article states that Texas ranked last in percentage of high school graduates in 2009, with 79.9% of Texans having graduated from high school. However, more recent data from 2011 shows that Texas tied with Mississippi and California for last place, with 81.1% of adults having high school degrees. In terms of funding for mental health patients, the article cites a report from the Henry J. Kaiser Family Foundation that shows Texas ranked last in per-resident spending on mental health care in 2009, 2008, and 2007. However, in fiscal 2010, Texas ranked 49th in per-person spending, with Idaho being the only state with lower spending. Overall, the article concludes that while two of the claims (high school graduates and mental health funding) are fairly solid, the claim takes things out of context by cherry-picking figures to make Texas look worse.
label: mixture
explanation: The Facebook post said: "Texas ranks: 1 in worker deaths, 1 carbon emissions, 50 in high school graduates, 50 in funding for mental health patients." This post takes things out of context by cherry-picking figures, in each case stressing the result that makes Texas look worst. Still, two of the declared ranks seem fairly solid. Texas tied with Mississippi in 2011 for the greatest share of adults lacking high school degrees and it was second to last in per-person mental health spending in 2010. In contrast, Texas ranked 22nd nationally in its 2011 worker fatality rate and while the state had the most carbon emissions in 2010, it would have tied for 13th if each state’s emissions were adjusted for its population.
summarized_main_text:
The claim states that Texas ranks #1 in worker deaths, #1 in carbon emissions, #50 in high school graduates, and #50 in funding for mental health patients. The article examines each of these claims individually. 

Regarding worker deaths, the article cites various sources that indicate Texas had the highest number of worker fatalities in 2010. However, when adjusting for population, Texas ranked 18th in worker deaths per 100,000 workers. Among states with more than 1 million employed, Texas ranked 10th. 

In terms of carbon emissions, Texas did have the highest amount of CO2 emissions in 2010. However, when adjusting for population, Texas would have tied for 13th place. The article also notes that Texas has a large number of industrial facilities, such as oil refineries and chemical plants, which contribute to its high emissions.

Regarding high school graduates, the article states that Texas ranked last in percentage of high school graduates in 2009, with 79.9% of Texans having graduated from high school. However, more recent data from 2011 shows that Texas tied with Mississippi and California for last place, with 81.1% of adults having high school degrees.

In terms of funding for mental health patients, the article cites a report from the Henry J. Kaiser Family Foundation that shows Texas ranked last in per-resident spending on mental health care in 2009, 2008, and 2007. However, in fiscal 2010, Texas ranked 49th in per-person spending, with Idaho being the only state with lower spending.

Overall, the article concludes that while two of the claims (high school graduates and mental health funding) are fairly solid, the claim takes things out of context by cherry-picking figures to make Texas look worse.

claim: U.S. says UCB cough medicine overdose can kill.
summarized_text: The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has issued an alert regarding the over-prescription and misuse of the cough medicine Tussionex Pennkinetic Extended-Release Suspension, manufactured by UCB. The FDA has received reports of doctors over-prescribing the medicine and individuals taking it more frequently than recommended, as well as giving it to children under the age of 6, despite it not being approved for that age group. Tussionex contains hydrocodone, a narcotic pain reliever, and excessive consumption can lead to life-threatening breathing problems. Since its approval in 1987, there have been reports of health problems and deaths among children and adults who took Tussionex. Five deaths have been reported among children under 6 who took the medicine. UCB has proposed a stronger warning for the medicine following these reports. The FDA is urging doctors and patients to follow prescribing instructions and use a medical syringe or other device designed to measure liquid medications, as household spoons vary in size and should not be used. UCB, based in Belgium, will update the Tussionex label to address these concerns. The FDA's alert aligns with UCB's efforts to ensure proper use of the product. The company had already taken steps to clarify the label in 2007. UCB does not plan to withdraw the product as the FDA alert only addresses improper use. In 2007, Tussionex sales in the U.S. totaled 114 million euros ($176 million).
label: true

The Swedish state alcohol retailer, Systembolaget, also withdrew Fireball from distribution after concerns over excessive levels of propylene glycol. The regulatory policies regarding propylene glycol in Finland and Sweden are stricter than in the US. The European Union permits smaller amounts of propylene glycol in products. The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) in the US considers propylene glycol to be safe when used in foods and beverages at levels not exceeding current good manufacturing practice. The rumors that Fireball was recalled in Europe because it contains antifreeze are inaccurate. Propylene glycol, which is found in Fireball, is less toxic and more environmentally safe than the antifreeze that contains ethylene glycol. The amount of propylene glycol used in foods and liquors is limited, and it would be difficult to ingest a dangerous amount through food or drink. The European recalls were not prompted by a change in Fireball's composition but rather due to differing regulatory protocols in different countries. Fireball issued a statement explaining that a logistical mix-up caused bottles intended for the North American market to be shipped to Finland. The brand assured consumers that all formulations are safe to drink and that there is no recall in North America. Fireball fans can continue to enjoy the product as they always have.
Claim: Fireball whisky is being recalled due to concerns over a dangerous ingredient.

The study looked at 10 different types of cancer and found that men with high calcium intake were 16% less likely to develop colon cancer over a 7-year period compared to those with the lowest calcium intake. However, the article fails to provide information on the absolute risk of colon cancer for these men, which is important in understanding the significance of the risk reduction.

The article also mentions that calcium intake above 1,200 milligrams per day did not show additional benefits, which is important to prevent people from excessively increasing their calcium intake. The strengths and weaknesses of the study are described, and it is noted that the study was large but not as rigorous as some smaller trials. Overall, the article provides information on the benefits of higher calcium intake in reducing cancer risk in older people, but fails to provide context on the absolute risk and risks of excessive calcium intake. It’s hard to tell how meaningful a 20 percent risk reduction of head and neck cancer is. One suspects the 7-year risk of those cancers in this population is very small, but we don’t know. There’s also an issue that isn’t captured by the criteria in this review but is worth mentioning nonetheless. It appears that most dietary calcium came from dairy products. If that’s true, do the researchers know whether something in the dairy products other than the calcium that is responsible for the risk reduction? The fact that calcium supplementation didn’t have the same protective effects as calcium-rich foods raises the question. The reporter should have too."}

claim: The sap of the giant hogweed plant can cause severe skin and eye irritation.
summarized_text: The article confirms the claim that the sap of the giant hogweed plant can cause severe skin and eye irritation. Giant hogweed is an invasive herb in the carrot family that was originally brought to North America from Asia. It has become established in various regions of the United States, including New England, the Mid-Atlantic, and the Northwest. The plant grows along streams and rivers, as well as in fields, forests, yards, and roadsides. It can reach a height of 14 feet or more, with compound leaves up to 5 feet in width. The sap of the giant hogweed contains toxic chemicals called furanocoumarins. When these chemicals come into contact with the skin and are exposed to sunlight, they cause a condition called phytophotodermatitis. This condition leads to reddening of the skin, followed by severe blistering and burns. The injuries can last for several months, and even after they have healed, the affected areas of skin can remain sensitive to light for years. Furanocoumarins are also carcinogenic and teratogenic, meaning they can cause cancer and birth defects. If the sap enters the eyes, it can cause temporary or even permanent blindness. If someone comes into physical contact with giant hogweed, it is recommended to take the following steps: if a reaction occurs, applying topical steroids early on may lessen the severity of the reaction and provide relief. The affected area of skin may remain sensitive to sunlight for a few years, so it is advised to apply sunblock and keep the affected area shielded from the sun whenever possible. The article also mentions that giant hogweed is not the only dangerous plant one might encounter. Other plants that can cause harm include oleander, a flowering shrub often used in gardens and along freeways, and sago palm, a decorative shrub found in gardens and homes. In conclusion, the article confirms that the sap of the giant hogweed plant can cause severe skin and eye irritation. It provides information about the plant's invasive nature, its growth habits, and the toxic chemicals present in its sap. It also offers recommendations for treating and preventing reactions to the sap.

explanation: Giant Hogweed Identification (New York State Department of Environmental Conservation)

The plant grows along streams and rivers, as well as in fields, forests, yards, and roadsides. It can reach a height of 14 feet or more, with compound leaves up to 5 feet in width.

The sap of the giant hogweed contains toxic chemicals called furanocoumarins. When these chemicals come into contact with the skin and are exposed to sunlight, they cause a condition called phytophotodermatitis. This condition leads to reddening of the skin, followed by severe blistering and burns. The injuries can last for several months, and even after they have healed, the affected areas of skin can remain sensitive to light for years. claim: Repeat blood clots more common with stents: study.
summarized_text: A study conducted by the Dutch Stent Thrombosis Study has found that one in six patients who suffer a clot inside a coronary stent are at risk of developing another clot. This risk is particularly high for patients who had a second stent implanted during emergency treatment for the first clot. The study, led by Dr. Jochem Wouter van Werkum of St. Antonius Hospital in the Netherlands, was presented at a joint meeting of the American College of Cardiology and the Society for Cardiovascular Angiography and Interventions in Chicago. Stents are wire mesh tubes that are inserted into the coronary arteries to keep them from reclogging after they have been cleared of blockages in an angioplasty procedure. However, clots can form inside the stent, known as stent thrombosis, which can block blood flow to the heart and lead to a heart attack or death. The researchers found that the use of an additional stent during emergency treatment of a stent-related blood clot is a strong predictor of repeat stent thrombosis. Patients who had a second stent implanted during emergency treatment were 4.2 times more likely to experience another episode of stent thrombosis. Patients who had previously had a heart attack were 2.6 times more likely, and those who developed a clot long after stent implantation, known as late stent thrombosis, were 2.1 times more likely to suffer a repeat episode. The study analyzed 437 patients with various types of stents who had experienced stent thrombosis between January 2004 and February 2007. Of these patients, 16.9 percent had multiple episodes of stent thrombosis, with 61 patients experiencing two episodes, 12 patients experiencing three episodes, and one patient experiencing four episodes. In conclusion, the study highlights the increased risk of repeat blood clots in patients who have had a coronary stent. The use of an additional stent during emergency treatment, a history of heart attack, and late stent thrombosis were identified as factors that increase the likelihood of experiencing another episode of stent thrombosis. These findings emphasize the importance of closely monitoring patients with stents to prevent further complications.

claim: Amazonian tribe study shows how human bodily bacteria is changing.
summarized_text: A study published in the journal Science Advances has found that the gut, mouth, and skin microbes of the Yanomami villagers, an isolated tribe in southern Venezuela's Amazonian jungles, possess the most diverse collection of bacteria ever found in humans. The Yanomami villagers, who were secluded from the outside world until 2009, have bacteria that include some never before detected in humans. Surprisingly, the researchers also found antibiotic-resistant genes in the Yanomami's microbes, even though they have never been exposed to commercial antibiotics. The human body hosts trillions of microbes, collectively known as the microbiota, which are essential for human health. However, modern practices such as processed foods and antibiotics have led to a decline in microbiota diversity. This decline may be linked to the increase in immunological and metabolic diseases such as asthma, allergies, diabetes, and obesity. The researchers analyzed microbial samples from 34 Yanomami villagers and compared them to a group from the United States, another indigenous group from the Venezuelan Amazonian region called the Guahibo, and residents of rural Malawi in southern Africa. The Yanomami villagers were found to have twice the number of microbe varieties compared to the U.S. subjects and 30 to 40 percent more diversity than the Malawians and Guahibo. Some of the bacteria found in the Yanomami but not in the other groups offer beneficial effects, such as protecting against kidney stones. The Yanomami villagers are semi-nomadic hunter-gatherers living in a remote mountainous region. The researchers believe that studying their microbiota provides a unique opportunity to understand the impact of modern practices on human bodily bacteria. The findings of this study suggest that the pre-modern human microbiota had a greater diversity of bacteria and bacterial functions compared to populations affected by modern practices. Overall, this study highlights how modern life may be altering humankind's bodily bacteria and the potential consequences of a decline in microbiota diversity.

Surprisingly, the researchers also found antibiotic-resistant genes in the Yanomami's microbes, even though they have never been exposed to commercial antibiotics.

The human body hosts trillions of microbes, collectively known as the microbiota, which are essential for human health. However, modern practices such as processed foods and antibiotics have led to a decline in microbiota diversity. This decline may be linked to the increase in immunological and metabolic diseases such as asthma, allergies, diabetes, and obesity.

The researchers analyzed microbial samples from 34 Yanomami villagers and compared them to a group from the United States, another indigenous group from the Venezuelan Amazonian region called the Guahibo, and residents of rural Malawi in southern Africa. The Yanomami villagers were found to have twice the number of microbe varieties compared to the U.S. subjects and 30 to 40 percent more diversity than the Malawians and Guahibo. Some of the bacteria found in the Yanomami but not in the other groups offer beneficial effects, such as protecting against kidney stones.

The Yanomami villagers are semi-nomadic hunter-gatherers living in a remote mountainous region. The researchers believe that studying their microbiota provides a unique opportunity to understand the impact of modern practices on human bodily bacteria. The findings of this study suggest that the pre-modern human microbiota had a greater diversity of bacteria and bacterial functions compared to populations affected by modern practices.

Overall, this study highlights how modern life may be altering humankind's bodily bacteria and the potential consequences of a decline in microbiota diversity.
Claim: Amazonian tribe study shows how human bodily bacteria is changing.

claim: Rhode Island’s teen binge drinking rate is double the national average.
summarized_text: The Washington, D.C.-based Physicians Committee for Responsible Medicine criticized a research study by Rhode Island Hospital and Brown University that uses young pigs to study the effects of alcohol consumption on the heart. The committee argued that the money spent on such research could be better used elsewhere in Rhode Island. They claimed that Rhode Island's teen binge drinking rate is double the national average and that the researchers are wasting federal funds on experiments giving alcohol to piglets. However, the claim made by the committee is incorrect. The most recent report that includes both national and state-by-state figures shows that Rhode Island's teen binge drinking rate is actually less than the national average. The committee acknowledged that they should have been more careful in their comparison and that they would have worded it differently if given the chance.
label: false
explanation: Regardless of your opinion on the larger point, the Physicians Committee for Responsible Medicine sought to make it with an incorrect comparison. It claimed "Rhode Island’s teen binge drinking rate is double the national average," deriving that claim by comparing numbers from two different surveys. But the most recent report that includes both national and state-by-state figures show that Rhode Island’s rate was actually less than the national average. We rule the claim False. (To check our sources and find additional information, go to the extended version of this article at PolitiFactRI.com.)

claim: Southern Illinois University starts marijuana, hemp research.
summarized_text: Southern Illinois University (SIU) has announced the creation of programs at its Carbondale campus to study medical marijuana and industrial hemp. The programs aim to provide students and farmers with the opportunity to earn a certificate in these subjects. The university has been planning for these programs for several years, taking into account requests and input from stakeholders and students who are interested in preparing for work in these areas. SIU's interdisciplinary program in cannabis science will combine agriculture and plant biology with courses in chemistry, business, and engineering. The program aims to support the emerging industry of hemp and medicinal cannabis, which have shown benefits in various areas such as health, quality of life, and the production of natural fibers. The university has already obtained approval from the Drug Enforcement Administration to grow hemp. In the spring, SIU plans to begin planting hemp on a 5-acre parcel of land, which will be divided into individual test plots to study specific research questions related to optimal growing conditions and environmental impact. Illinois has allowed the sale of medical marijuana since 2015, but only to patients with a limited number of documented conditions. However, in August, Governor Bruce Rauner signed legislation expanding access to medical cannabis and permitting its use as a painkiller. Rauner also lifted the state ban on planting hemp. SIU's decision to offer programs in marijuana and hemp research aligns with the growing trend of colleges and universities across the country providing courses related to cannabis. The university aims to meet the demand for scientific knowledge in this field and position itself to support the emerging industry.
label: true
explanation: Southern Illinois University is creating new programs for students who want to know more about marijuana.
summarized_main_text:
Southern Illinois University (SIU) has announced the creation of programs at its Carbondale campus to study medical marijuana and industrial hemp. The programs aim to provide students and farmers with the opportunity to earn a certificate in these subjects. claim: If Cory Gardner gets his way, you'd better stock up on condoms.
summarized_text: The article discusses a television ad in Colorado's Senate race between Mark Udall and Cory Gardner that focuses on the topics of abortion and birth control. The ad claims that if Cory Gardner gets his way, people should stock up on condoms because he wants to ban birth control. The ad is sponsored by NARAL Pro-Choice America and NARAL Pro-Choice Colorado and is aimed at reaching young voters. The Gardner campaign denies the claim made in the ad and states that Gardner does not want to ban condoms. They clarify that Gardner believes in increased access to contraceptives and has proposed making common forms of oral contraception available over the counter. The ad's claim is based on Gardner's support of "personhood" measures that define life beginning at fertilization. Gardner co-sponsored a bill known as the Life At Conception Act, which declares that the right to life guaranteed by the Constitution is vested in each human being, including at the moment of fertilization. Opponents of personhood legislation argue that it could make several FDA-approved contraceptives illegal. However, the article points out that even Gardner acknowledges that some contraceptives could be at risk if personhood passed, but there is still legal ambiguity. No state has passed a personhood measure, so the impact on specific types of contraceptives is unknown. The article also mentions that Gardner has changed his position on personhood during the 2014 campaign, stating that he no longer supports it because it could potentially impact access to certain forms of birth control. He has also expressed support for allowing the birth control pill to be sold over-the-counter without a prescription. ### Instruction:
Use the Task below and the Input given to write the Response, which is a veracity label prediction and the reason explanation for your prediction that can solve the Task.
            

### Task:
Based only on the context, categorize the claim as:
- True (supported by context)
- False (contradicted by context)
- Mixture (partially supported/contradicted)
- Unproven (not enough info)
And explain your reasoning. Provide the response in JSON format with the following keys: veracity, explanation.

### Input:
Context: The claim that Fireball whisky is being recalled due to concerns over a dangerous ingredient is partially true. In October 2014, there were rumors on social media that Fireball whisky was being recalled, causing upset among consumers. However, no news reports confirmed this recall. It was later revealed that while Fireball whisky was not being broadly recalled, it was the subject of scrutiny and a partial recall in Finland and Sweden due to the inclusion of propylene glycol. Finland's liquor retail agency, Alko, recalled Fireball and offered refunds, stating that propylene glycol is not necessarily detrimental to health but is used in a wide range of products. The Swedish state alcohol retailer, Systembolaget, also withdrew Fireball from distribution after concerns over excessive levels of propylene glycol. The regulatory policies regarding propylene glycol in Finland and Sweden are stricter than in the US. The European Union permits smaller amounts of propylene glycol in products. The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) in the US considers propylene glycol to be safe when used in foods and beverages at levels not exceeding current good manufacturing practice. The rumors that Fireball was recalled in Europe because it contains antifreeze are inaccurate. Propylene glycol, which is found in Fireball, is less toxic and more environmentally safe than the antifreeze that contains ethylene glycol. The amount of propylene glycol used in foods and liquors is limited, and it would be difficult to ingest a dangerous amount through food or drink. The European recalls were not prompted by a change in Fireball's composition but rather due to differing regulatory protocols in different countries. Fireball issued a statement explaining that a logistical mix-up caused bottles intended for the North American market to be shipped to Finland. The brand assured consumers that all formulations are safe to drink and that there is no recall in North America. Fireball fans can continue to enjoy the product as they always have.
Claim: Fireball whisky is being recalled due to concerns over a dangerous ingredient.

### Response:
{"veracity":"mixture","explanation":"What's true: In 2014, some Scandinavian state agencies recalled Fireball whisky until they could determine if it met local regulations regarding propylene glycol content. What's false: Fireball whisky has been broadly recalled from all markets because it contains antifreeze."}

### Input:
Context: A study has found that higher calcium intake is associated with a lower risk of cancer in older people. The study looked at 10 different types of cancer and found that men with high calcium intake were 16% less likely to develop colon cancer over a 7-year period compared to those with the lowest calcium intake. However, the article fails to provide information on the absolute risk of colon cancer for these men, which is important in understanding the significance of the risk reduction.

The article also mentions that calcium intake above 1,200 milligrams per day did not show additional benefits, which is important to prevent people from excessively increasing their calcium intake. However, it does not mention the risks of excessive calcium intake, such as kidney problems and malabsorption of other minerals.

The strengths and weaknesses of the study are described, and it is noted that the study was large but not as rigorous as some smaller trials. The results are not conclusive, and the study population is likely healthier than the general population, which is important to consider when interpreting the findings.

The article does a good job of sourcing, including the thoughts of the lead researcher and three independent experts. However, it is worth noting that none of the experts are quoted directly, their viewpoints are paraphrased.

The article properly distinguishes between calcium from diet and supplements, and mentions that the study does not make claims for the novelty of a calcium-rich diet or the general findings. The availability of calcium-rich foods and supplements is not in question.

Overall, the article provides information on the benefits of higher calcium intake in reducing cancer risk in older people, but fails to provide context on the absolute risk and risks of excessive calcium intake. It also does a good job of sourcing and describing the strengths and weaknesses of the study.
Claim: Calcium tied to lower cancer risk in older people

### Response:
{"veracity":"true","explanation":"This report on a study about the links between calcium intake and cancer risk does several important things well: It puts these findings in the context of other research It translates the calcium amounts into dietary choices It describes the methodology and conclusions clearly, and includes useful caveats It makes the useful distinction between the benefits of calcium from diet and supplements It packs in the viewpoints of four sources into a fairly short story The story’s biggest shortcoming is a failure to put the relative risk reductions in the context of absolute risk. It’s hard to tell how meaningful a 20 percent risk reduction of head and neck cancer is. One suspects the 7-year risk of those cancers in this population is very small, but we don’t know. There’s also an issue that isn’t captured by the criteria in this review but is worth mentioning nonetheless. It appears that most dietary calcium came from dairy products. If that’s true, do the researchers know whether something in the dairy products other than the calcium that is responsible for the risk reduction? The fact that calcium supplementation didn’t have the same protective effects as calcium-rich foods raises the question. The reporter should have too."}

Context: The claim that a Minnesota man was jailed simply for possessing a windmill on his property is not entirely accurate. The man, Jay Nygard, had been in a years-long dispute with local authorities over his installation of a wind turbine on his property. The city of Orono had ordered Nygard to stop work on the wind turbine, as it violated zoning regulations. Nygard continued to press ahead with the installation, pouring a concrete pad for the turbine after his building permit application was rejected. The city threatened him with criminal prosecution if he did not remove the turbine.

The dispute between Nygard and the city of Orono resulted in multiple lawsuits and a moratorium on small wind conversion systems in the city. Nygard was found to be in contempt of court in October 2015 for failing to comply with an order to remove the turbine's concrete footing. He was sentenced to six months in jail, but the concrete was removed shortly after his sentencing, and he was released after a few days.

The article highlights that stories like Nygard's are often misconstrued or misrepresented as examples of an overreaching government restricting autonomous lifestyles. Similar stories, such as a man being jailed for collecting rainwater or a judge ruling homegrown vegetables unlawful, have been distorted to fit this narrative. In reality, these disputes often involve specific cases and do not represent a widespread crackdown on self-sustainability.

In conclusion, while Jay Nygard did face legal consequences for his wind turbine installation, the claim that he was jailed simply for possessing a windmill on his property oversimplifies the complex legal dispute between Nygard and the city of Orono.
Claim: A Minnesota man was jailed simply for possessing a windmill on his property.

### Response:
{"veracity":"false","explanation":"What's true: Minnesota man Jay Nygard was jailed in October 2015 after being found in contempt of court for refusing to comply with an order to remove a concrete base from his property. What's false: Nygard was not thrown in jail for simply erecting a windmill; Nygard did not spend six months in jail."}

claim: Darrell Issa Says Thomas Eric Duncan came into the United States "with an elevated temperature.
summarized_text: The article discusses the recent increase in Ebola screening guidelines at airports in New York, New Jersey, and Illinois. These guidelines require anyone passing through the airports who had contact with Ebola patients, even if they are not showing symptoms, to be quarantined. The article mentions that these guidelines have been subject to criticism, particularly from administration officials, who argue that they are unnecessary. The article also mentions that JFK, Newark, and O'Hare airports already have screening processes in place, along with three other American airports. Experts say that people who are not showing symptoms of Ebola are not contagious. The article then discusses the case of Thomas Eric Duncan, the first patient diagnosed with Ebola in the United States. It states that Duncan did not have a fever when he left Monrovia, Liberia, where he had been screened for Ebola. However, he did not report falling ill until several days after arriving in the United States. The article notes that it is unclear whether Duncan had a fever when he arrived in the United States, as American airports were not yet screening travelers for possible signs of Ebola at that time. The article also mentions that airport screenings in West African airports, like the one Duncan went through, have been taking place since at least August. These screenings involve taking travelers' temperatures, answering health questionnaires, and visually assessing them for signs of illness. The article states that screenings are also taking place at airports in England, Belgium, France, Hong Kong, Egypt, Canada, and now the United States. The article concludes by stating that the CDC and Department of Homeland Security instituted new airport screening guidelines in early October for travelers from Liberia, Guinea, and Sierra Leone arriving at five major American airports. These guidelines require travelers to go through an Ebola screening process, including temperature checks and questions about possible exposure. The article notes that even with these screening measures in place, it is possible that Duncan would have passed without showing a fever or other symptoms. Overall, the article provides information about the recent increase in Ebola screening guidelines at airports and discusses the case of Thomas Eric Duncan, who was the first patient diagnosed with Ebola in the United States. It highlights the uncertainty surrounding whether Duncan had a fever when he arrived in the United States and mentions the existing airport screenings in West Africa and other countries.
label: false
explanation: Issa said Thomas Eric Duncan came into the United States "with an elevated temperature." According to the CDC, Duncan did not have a fever when he left Monrovia. At the time, American airports were not screening travelers, so there’s no way for us (or Issa) to know definitively if he had a fever when he got to the United States. But he did not report falling ill until several days after arriving, when he went to the hospital with a fever. It’s possible that even if current screening measures had been in place, Duncan would have passed without showing a fever or other symptoms.

claim: The legislation ... that Senator McCain supports would provide the authority for the federal government to surveille American citizens in their own country without any suspicion whatsoever that they're engaging in discussions with terrorists or about criminal activity.
summarized_text: The article discusses the challenges faced by the central German city of Ruesselsheim in its plan to build 1,300 electric car charging points by 2020. The city has received a government grant of 12.8 million euros to fund the project, but officials anticipate delays due to red tape, shortages of qualified staff, and the complexity of civil engineering and power grid overloads. The article highlights the growing number of electric cars in Germany and Europe, but notes that the charging infrastructure is not keeping pace with the demand. This could potentially hinder sales and the European Union's plan to become "carbon neutral" by 2050. The lack of off-street parking in some areas is also mentioned as a deterrent for drivers to switch to electric cars. Ruesselsheim aims to provide one charging point per 72 people, the highest level in Europe, with the help of carmaker Opel and the local RheinMain University. However, the installation of each charging point requires approval from various authorities and charging equipment makers have long lead times. The article also mentions the complications of different charging and payment processes across the country, as well as the funding challenges faced by Germany and other countries in expanding the charging infrastructure. The reluctance of energy providers to invest in the infrastructure while car sales remain low is highlighted as a potential obstacle. Without a sufficient number of charging stations, customers may be hesitant to switch to electric cars, creating a vicious circle. The article concludes by stating that the legislation supported by Senator McCain would give the federal government the authority to surveil American citizens without any suspicion of terrorist activities or criminal behavior.

Context: The claim that Fireball whisky is being recalled due to concerns over a dangerous ingredient is partially true. In October 2014, there were rumors on social media that Fireball whisky was being recalled, causing upset among consumers. However, no news reports confirmed this recall. It was later revealed that while Fireball whisky was not being broadly recalled, it was the subject of scrutiny and a partial recall in Finland and Sweden due to the inclusion of propylene glycol. Finland's liquor retail agency, Alko, recalled Fireball and offered refunds, stating that propylene glycol is not necessarily detrimental to health but is used in a wide range of products. The Swedish state alcohol retailer, Systembolaget, also withdrew Fireball from distribution after concerns over excessive levels of propylene glycol. The regulatory policies regarding propylene glycol in Finland and Sweden are stricter than in the US. The European Union permits smaller amounts of propylene glycol in products. The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) in the US considers propylene glycol to be safe when used in foods and beverages at levels not exceeding current good manufacturing practice. The rumors that Fireball was recalled in Europe because it contains antifreeze are inaccurate. Propylene glycol, which is found in Fireball, is less toxic and more environmentally safe than the antifreeze that contains ethylene glycol. The amount of propylene glycol used in foods and liquors is limited, and it would be difficult to ingest a dangerous amount through food or drink. The European recalls were not prompted by a change in Fireball's composition but rather due to differing regulatory protocols in different countries. Fireball issued a statement explaining that a logistical mix-up caused bottles intended for the North American market to be shipped to Finland. The brand assured consumers that all formulations are safe to drink and that there is no recall in North America. Fireball fans can continue to enjoy the product as they always have.
Claim: Fireball whisky is being recalled due to concerns over a dangerous ingredient.

The study looked at 10 different types of cancer and found that men with high calcium intake were 16% less likely to develop colon cancer over a 7-year period compared to those with the lowest calcium intake. However, the article fails to provide information on the absolute risk of colon cancer for these men, which is important in understanding the significance of the risk reduction.

The article also mentions that calcium intake above 1,200 milligrams per day did not show additional benefits, which is important to prevent people from excessively increasing their calcium intake. However, it does not mention the risks of excessive calcium intake, such as kidney problems and malabsorption of other minerals.

The strengths and weaknesses of the study are described, and it is noted that the study was large but not as rigorous as some smaller trials. The results are not conclusive, and the study population is likely healthier than the general population, which is important to consider when interpreting the findings.

The article does a good job of sourcing, including the thoughts of the lead researcher and three independent experts. However, it is worth noting that none of the experts are quoted directly, their viewpoints are paraphrased.

The article properly distinguishes between calcium from diet and supplements, and mentions that the study does not make claims for the novelty of a calcium-rich diet or the general findings. The availability of calcium-rich foods and supplements is not in question.

Overall, the article provides information on the benefits of higher calcium intake in reducing cancer risk in older people, but fails to provide context on the absolute risk and risks of excessive calcium intake. It also does a good job of sourcing and describing the strengths and weaknesses of the study.
Claim: Calcium tied to lower cancer risk in older people
